title: Brisbane 2032 venues to be revealed
text:
Thank you for joining us for live coverage on a busy day in the newsroom.

The Labor government will hand down its fourth budget tonight but before that we are set to find out where the Brisbane Olympics 2032 main stadium will be, where the sports will be hosted and what's in store for the Brisbane Arena plan, as the Olympic and Paralympic Games plans are revealed.

- Watch 9News coverage from ﻿12.15pm AEST at the top of this page

title: 'Trump-proofing' and billions in cost-of-living relief to figure in federal budget
text:
Treasurer Jim Chalmers will aim to protect Australian industry against the impacts of Donald Trump's tariffs when he hands down the federal budget tonight.

The dangers of a full-blown global trade war and the damage to exporters from the US president's tariffs will shape this budget, as the federal government gears up for an election in May .

The budget is expected to push a "buy Australian" plan to shield local businesses from the economic disruptions sparked by Trump's tariffs, reports The Sydney Morning Herald.

Treasurer Jim Chalmers will hand down the federal budget today.. (Polly Hanning/Nine)

It will involve spending by government departments favouring Australian companies and encouraging households to buy locally.﻿

That goes hand in hand with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's election platform for a "future made in Australia".

Australian beef and pharmaceuticals are expected to be targeted in the next round of US tariffs, due to be unveiled by the White House next week.

But with one eye on the US, the treasurer has the other on delivering substantial cost-of-living relief for families in the national accounts, including extended energy rebates, ahead of the looming election.

The federal budget will also contain an extra $10.6 billion for defence spending over four years as the Trump administration pushes US allies to contribute more for their armed forces. ﻿

Here's what﻿ you can expect today.

Major bulk-billing boost and cheaper PBS medicines

Health ﻿has been a significant focus for the government in the lead-up to the next election, highlighted by two major policy announcements.

The first, unveiled in February, is an $8.5 billion boost for Medicare to expand bulk billing in a policy it says will deliver 18 million extra bulk-billed GP visits each year, saving Australians a combined $859 million a year by 2030.

The second, announced just days from the budget, is a $689 million pledge to reduce the maximum cost of a majority of medicines listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), down from $31.60 to $25﻿.

That second announcement, which comes as US pharmaceutical giants lobby President Donald Trump to target the PBS in a new round of tariffs, will deliver Australians combined savings of $200 million a year, according to the government, and will start on January 1, 2026.

Both policies have been backed by the opposition, so will come into effect regardless of who wins the next election.

Many medicines listed on the PBS will get cheaper from January 1, 2026. (Nine)

Energy bill relief

The centrepiece of last year's budget was the $3.5 billion in energy bill relief – an automatic $300 rebate, spread over the course of the financial year, for every household in the country, and that is, as expected, being extended this year.

The policy will now run through until the end of the year, providing all Australian households with a further﻿ $150 off their power bills , at a cost of $1.8 billion.

It comes after the national energy regulator approved price increases of up to 9 per cent from July 1.

According to Treasury estimates, the move will reduce headline inflation by around half a percentage point, and reduce household bills by 7.5 per cent on average nationally.

While the opposition slammed the move as a "desperate act" and a "Ponzi scheme", it also promised to support the move so, once again, it will be implemented regardless of the election result.

The government says the extension of energy relief will reduce household bills by 7.5 per cent. (Luis Enrique Ascui/The Age)

Boost for Australian-made goods as tariffs hit

One of the big economic uncertainties plaguing financial markets at the moment is US President Donald Trump's explosion of tariffs.

Australia has been hit by Trump's 25 per cent ﻿tax on all steel and aluminium imported into the United States, and while we shouldn't expect a retaliatory tariff in the budget – that was ruled out by Albanese – there's set to be some kind of response.

Local manufacturers fear a flood of cheap, international produce onto the Australian market from all the other nations that have also been denied free access to American consumers, which would be a significant business challenge.

Albanese has flagged support for local industry will be handed down.

"In the March budget, we'll provide additional support for our 'Buy Australian' campaign which we'll be announcing as part of the budget process," the prime minister said in his press conference responding to the introduction of Trump's tariffs.

A couple of days later, he gave another hint on the topics.

"We have great products and as part of the budget in a couple of weeks' time, you'll see a spiced-up Made in Australia Plan﻿," he said.

Expect to see incentives for Australians to buy locally made products after Donald Trump's steel and aluminium tariffs. (AAP)

A budget deficit

﻿After two straight years of surpluses, the budget will return to the red in 2025.

﻿This has been flagged for quite some time; last year's surplus was always forecast to be followed by a return to deficit. (To put things into context, 2023 and 2024 are the only two surpluses Australia has recorded since 2008.)

While we don't know what the exact figure will be, in December's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook (MYEFO), Treasury was forecasting a deficit of $26.9 billion in this year's budget.

A week before budget day, Chalmers said that figure will be pretty close to the mark.

"Revenue upgrades have actually come off very significantly since the highs of October 2022," he said.

"Treasury doesn't expect the bottom line this year or over the forward estimates to change very substantially from MYEFO."﻿

Chalmers has flagged the deficit is likely to be in the mid-$20 billions. (Alex Ellinghausen/SMH)

Massive student debt discount

The roughly 3 million Australians who have student debt will get a welcome boost on June 1 when ﻿their outstanding balances are cut by 20 per cent .

The one-off discount represents a massive $16 billion in student debt reduction – more than five times larger than last year's move to retrospectively lower the indexation applied to those debts.

The new measure was announced by the government as an election promise in November, and will now need to be included in this year's budget.

All Australians with student debt will get a big saving following the budget. (Louie Douvis/AFR)

Subsidised childcare for everyone﻿

Like﻿ the student debt discount, this was an election promise unveiled in late 2024, well after the last budget: three days a week of subsidised childcare to families with a combined income of less than $530,000 a year.

The activity test will also be scrapped to make it easier for low-income parents to access cheaper childcare, a measure recommended by the Productivity Commission and long called for by economists.

The policy will come into effect on January 1, 2026, if Labor wins the federal election, and will cost $427 million over five years.

Albanese and Education Minister Jason Clare (right) unveiled the childcare changes last year. (Paul Jeffers/The Age)

Other announcements ﻿

There are a number of other policies that will form a part of the 2025 federal budget, including:

A new $1 billion fund to build and expand early education centres﻿

$1 billion ﻿to reserve land for a future rail line linking Western Sydney Airport with south-west Sydney suburbs

$30 million for the restoration of the Adass Israel Synagogue, which was firebombed last year, as well as a further $1.2 million for security upgrades.﻿

$2.9 million to help grocery suppliers "stand up" to Woolworths and Coles.

A $44.5 million boost for Australia's intelligence capabilities to implement the recommendations of an independent review.

$800 million to expand the eligibility criteria for the Help to Buy shared equity housing scheme .

﻿$54 million to boost the prefabricated home construction industry.
